keyTakeAways: The White House has begun demolishing part of the East Wing to build a $250 million ballroom, despite lacking formal approval from the National Capital Planning Commission.
The project is being privately funded by Trump and various businesses, with no cost to taxpayers, and includes a donation of HVAC systems from Carrier Global Corp.
The new ballroom will be 90,000 square feet with a capacity of 999 people, significantly larger than the original East Room's 200-person capacity.
The East Wing, built in 1902 and renovated in 1942, currently houses offices including those of the First Lady and will be temporarily relocated during construction.
Trump claims the ballroom is a long-desired feature, citing a 150-year history of presidential desire, and asserts it avoids touching the main structure of the White House.
The National Capital Planning Commission has not approved the project, and the White House argues that it does not have jurisdiction over demolition and site prep work.
The White House has not disclosed detailed donor information for the project, though it has confirmed Carrier's donation of an energy-efficient HVAC system.
The demolition and construction are taking place without official federal approval, raising questions about compliance with government project oversight procedures.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The White House has begun demolishing part of the East Wing to construct a $250 million, 90,000-square-foot ballroom, despite lacking formal approval from the National Capital Planning Commission, the federal body responsible for overseeing such projects. President Donald Trump announced the project in July, asserting it would not interfere with the main White House structure and would be privately funded by donors and himself, with no cost to taxpayers. The new ballroom, designed to seat 999 people, is intended to address the perceived limitations of the existing East Room. Construction began in September with site prep and demolition, with the East Wing offices being temporarily relocated. Carrier Global Corp has donated HVAC systems for the ballroom, and the project is projected to be completed by January 2029. The White House has not disclosed full donor information, and the lack of regulatory approval raises concerns about compliance with federal oversight standards.
title: The White House starts demolishing part of the East Wing to build Trump's ballroom
